title: My Novel Write Now (MyNoWriNo)
body:
Frameworks used: UIKit, EventKit

Contributions: Team lead, worked on all parts of the project.

My Novel Write Now's main purpose is to provide an interface for writers, or anyone working on a writing project, to track their progress. Many writing projects (or competitions, such as National Novel Writing Month) have a minimum word count goal and a deadline. My Novel Write Now allows the user to create a project that takes this information as input, allows the user to record their daily wordcount, and track their overall progress. My Novel Write Now can also save a project's deadline into the user's calendar (via the Calendar App) so that they are reminded of upcoming due dates. I worked on this project with Corey Malek.

title: Hike Washington
body:
Libraries/Packages used: jQuery, Web SQL, Express, page.js, handlebars.js

Contributions: MVC Architecture layout, ­ Overall user experience design, AJAX process,­ Google API geolocation,­ distance filtering,­ data management and refactoring, HTML template rendering for results, routing and page.js

APIs used: Trails, Google Maps

Hike Washington is a website that allows users to search for hikes in Washington State by zipcode, and refine their results based on length, scenery, and other available outdoor activities. Our hike data comes from the Trails API, and is stored using Web SQL. We we used the Google Maps API for the initial zipcode search. I worked on this project with Corey Malek, Kaylyn Yuh and Doug Christ.

The project had the following requirements:

Obvious MVC/REST Architecture

  • Single page application style
  • Clearly defined resources
  • Resource data is persisted by a database
  • Resources have well factored and isolated MVC components
  • URLs use a conventional REST design for resources.

Good and Proper Use of HTML

  • Clear, readable, and efficient structure
  • Uses semantic markup whenever possible

Good and Proper Use of CSS

  • Clear, readable, and efficient styles
  • Layout on various screen sizes like desktop and mobile
  • Well organized file structure

Good and Proper Use of JavaScript

  • Clear, readable, and efficient code
  • Uses domain models to encapsulate data and behavior (OOP)
  • Responds to user events
  • Leverages AJAX appropriately in at least one case
  • Integrates 3rd party libraries like jQuery consistently
  • Contains no unnecessary or commented­ out code

Generally Useful and Functional

  • Works as expected with no bugs
  • Has at least 3 interlinked 'pages' with a clear navigation
  • Has at least two pages that accept and process user input
  • State is persisted between page reloads

title: CFuWx
body:
Frameworks used: Charts, Parse, Parse Server, CoreData, CoreLocation, CoreMotion

APIs used: Dark Sky Weather API

Contributions: Team lead, worked on all parts of the project.

CFuWx is a weather forecast app that allows users to participate in crowd-sourced weather data collection. Built as a final project for the Code Fellows Certificate in Advanced Software Development in iOS, this project was based on uWx, an Andriod app developed by the University of Washington Department of Atmospheric Sciences. I worked on this project with Corey Malek and Jake Dobson.

title: Eat Fellows
body:
Contributions: Created the overall design, worked on multiple aspects of the project.

Week 4 of Code Fellows 201 was spent working on a group project. My team built a site that gives CF students a map of local places to go for lunch.

The project used only local storage to save new restaurants and reviews, since working with databases is not within the scope of the 201 class. I worked on the project with David Smith, Val Craig, and Logan Rogers

The project had the following requirements (from the description of the project):

  • There can be no more than 3-4 people per team.
  • Each person must make meaningful contributions in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
  • Your web site must have at least 3 interlinked pages and clear navigation.
  • Your web site must have at least 2 pages that accept and process user input.
  • Your web site's state must persist between page reloads.
  • Your web site must be deployed live on the Internet.

title: BusMall
body:
My week 3 Code Fellows lab project. The project simulates a marketing survey for a company that wants to build a SkyMall-style buisiness based on local transit. The goal of the project was to learn how to work with local storage, JSON files, and get some practice working with JavaScript libraries, in particular the Chart.js library.

From the lab assignment:

“To make this market analysis maximally effective, BusMall wants you to build an app that displays potential products to individuals in focus groups (three products at a time, side-by-side-by-side, so you'll need to manage the size and the aspect ratio of the images and perhaps edit them a bit; Mac users can do this in Preview (very cool!), plus, there are lots of online tools.

“The app's purpose is to have the group members choose which product, of the three displayed images, that they would be most likely to purchase, and then store, calculate, and visually display the resulting data.

“To keep the product selection process as untainted as possible, you have been instructed to not allow any results to be shown to users until there have been a total of 25 selections made.

The marketing team is not only interested in the total number of clicks, but also the percentage of times that an item was clicked when it was shown. So, you'll also need to keep track of how many times each image is displayed and do the calculations.

“You are also responsible for the look and feel of the app, so don't forget a custom font, color palette, layout with semantic HTML, and so on.”

title: Learning Journal
body: One of my assignments for CF 201 was a daily learning journal, used to reflect on what I'd learned on any given day. I tried to put in at least one small bit of code each day, as well as bullet point “things to remember”.

title: Python Learning Journal
body: Learning Journal class project using Pyramid for UWPCE Python 200, Winter 2016

title: Cookie Stand
body: For this week-long lab assignment, we built a website for a fictional company called Pat's Salmon Cookies.
